title: NEC Controls HEMS by Predicting Amount of Solar Power Generation
text:
NEC Controls HEMS by Predicting Amount of Solar Power Generation NEC Controls HEMS by Predicting Amount of Solar Power Generation 2015/10/14 18:12 Kenji Kaneko, Nikkei BP CleanTech Institute A screen for the "visualization" of power consumption (source: NEC) The information collecting unit of the cloud-based HEMS (source: NEC) 
NEC Corp announced that it will release a cloud-based HEMS (home energy management system) capable of predicting the amount of solar electricity generated based on weather forecasts and automatically controlling a power storage system. 
NEC will start to ship the HEMS in late November 2015 to housing manufacturers, solar power generation facility manufacturers, etc. It aims to sell about 100,000 units of the system in three years. 
The company intends to make the new product support other companies' devices equipped with a power measurement function, planning to enable it to work in conjunction with Omron Corp's measurement unit for residential solar power generation systems as a starter. 
The new product predicts the amount of solar electricity to be generated on the next day based on weather forecasts and automatically controls the timing of charging NEC's small power storage system. 
For example, when it is forecast to be cloudy on the next day, the amount of solar electricity is predicted to be small during daylight hours and, therefore, the system charges the battery by using nighttime power in the night before. As a result, the power storage system can be efficiently charged by using solar power and inexpensive nighttime power, potentially improving economic efficiency, NEC said. 
Furthermore, the system can measure power consumption for each breaker (for a living room, kitchen, etc) and receive accurate power consumption data of an entire house from a smart meter (compatible with B route). Measured data can be sorted by momentary value, day, month, year, etc and visualized as graphs, leading to energy-conscious behaviors.
